tn.text: These are the names of two men. They were spoken of in [[:en:bible:notes:est:02:19|2:21]], but Bigthana's name was spelled "Bigthan" there. You may translate his name as you did there or according to how it is spelled in this verse. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

Here "found" is an metaphor for learning. Both "found" and "recorded" can be expressed in active form. AT: "They found that the writers had recorded there" or "They learned that the writers had written" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: What was done to give honor
tn.text: This can be expressed in active form. AT: "What did I do to give honor" or "What did we do to give honor " (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This can be expressed in active form. However it may be good to find a way that does not give them impression that servants were accusing the king. AT: "No one did anything for Mordecai" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Translate this man's name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:03:01|3:1]]
"the first courtyard from the outside"
It can be made clear what the purpose of hanging him was. AT: "killing Mordecai by hanging him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]]

tn.ref: the gallows he set up for him
tn.text: The gallows was a structure that was used to kill people by hanging them from it. See how you translated "gallows" in [[:en:bible:notes:est:05:14|5:14]]. AT: "the structure he set up for hanging him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"built"

tn.ref: the king takes pleasure in honoring
tn.text: Taking pleasure in doing something is an idiom for being glad to do something or wanting to do something. AT: "the king is glad to honor" or "the king wants to honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The heart represents the thoughts and attitudes. AT: "thought" or "said to himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Whom would the king take pleasure in honoring more than me?
tn.text: This can be expressed as a statement. "Surely there is no one whom the king would take greater pleasure in honoring more than me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "let someone bring royal robes" or "tell your servants to bring royal robes"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: on whose head is the royal crest
tn.text: The word "whose" refers to the horse. The royal crest is a special symbol that represents the king's family.

tn.ref: Then let the robes and the horse be given
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. "Then let them give the robes and the horse" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Let noble official and servants proclaim"

tn.ref: Do not fail in a single matter of what you have said
tn.text: The phrase "a single matter" emphasizes that he must do absolutely everything he said. It can be stated positively. AT: "Be sure do absolutely everything you have said"
People often covered their head to show that they were either extremely sad or ashamed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Translate this woman's name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:06:12|6:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: before whom you have begun to fall
tn.text: They spoke as if Haman and Mordecai were in a battle, and Haman was beginning to lose the battle. Losing the battle represents being dishonored. AT: "before whom you are becoming less honored" or "before whom you are being humiliated (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

"you will not win against him." They spoke as if Haman and Mordecai were in a battle. Overcoming someone represents having greater honor than him. AT: "you will not have greater honor than he has" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you will certainly fall before him
tn.text: They spoke as if Haman and Mordecai were in a battle. Falling, or losing the battle, represents being dishonored. AT: "you will certainly be dishonored before him" or "you will certainly be humiliated before him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
